title: HiveMind - Freshwater Quality in NZ
text:
This HiveMind is now closed. Thank you to the 117 participants who voted and submitted statements.

The graphic visualisation below shows the participants grouped in clusters based on shared opinions.

comments.text: Water is a commodity
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: No had any of the listed issues so a disagree vote
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Irrigation can allow for higher value horticultural crops to be grown
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Encouraging wider use of rainwater harvesting and greywater recycling for uses outside of human consumption will save valuable potable water and reduce load on water infrastructure.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Regional councils are underfunded and too political to ensure appropriate compliance and monitoring of environmental issues.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Heavy tax on water in plastic bottles
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The use of weed control sprays such as Roundup by councils around our waterways needs to stop.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Irrigation can allow for higher value horticultural crops to be grown in a manner that reduces nutrient losses to water ways
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Water of potable quality is not required for any plants or toilet flushing etc. We should consider rainwater harvesting such things.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The 7 steps of the Freshwater Rescue Plan (by a cross sector alliance of advocacy groups) should be adopted 1. Set strict and enforceable standards. 2. End public irrigation subsidies. 3. Create an Agricultural Transition Fund. 4. Decrease cow numbers. 5. Create polluter pays systems. 6. Support regional councils. 7. Transition to a low-carbon economy https://www.freshwaterrescueplan.org/the-plan/
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The 7 steps recommended by the Freshwater Rescue Plan (a cross sector alliance of advocacy groups) should be adopted: 1. Set strict and enforceable standards. 2. End public irrigation subsidies. 3. Create an Agricultural Transition Fund. 4. Decrease cow numbers. 5. Create polluter pays systems. 6. Support regional councils. 7. Transition to a low-carbon economy https://www.freshwaterrescueplan.org
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The heavy use of weed control sprays, 1080 and Brodifacum by councils around our waterways needs to stop.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: No one should be granted private property rights over vital natural resources such as fresh water
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Everyone has a right to access and use freshwater water resources, not just those who own land beside a river/stream or over an aquifer.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: NZ should learn from countries with higher populations, like Australia and Europe, as to how best to protect water quality in urban areas
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Minimum flow requirements to protect freshwater ecosystems and recreational use should be set for all rivers and streams
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: NZ needs better integration of land and water management. Modern sources of water pollution largely stem from poor land management.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: New developments must be required to comply with best practice management of erosion, sediment run-off and stormwater.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Citizens have a right to clean potable water for drinking, cooking & food growing. Water for ornamental gardens/lawns/car washing etc is a desirable luxury not a right.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Foreign companies should be encouraged to invest in & provide local jobs in water-consuming industries & farming.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The Monetisation and sale of are water supply will lead to the decline of New Zealand
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Aquifers only have the ability to come back into balance over decades so a precautionary approach is required.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Gifting farmers to build irrigation with millions of taxpayer money is justified as it will benefit them.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There is not a freshwater management crisis in New Zealand and nothing needs to be done about it.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Potable water is a finite resource.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Foreign companies should be encouraged to invest & provide local jobs in water-consuming industries & farming.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Citizens have a right to clean potable water for drinking & cooking. Water for gardens/car washing etc is a desirable luxury not a right.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: New urban development needs to include active stormwater and erosion/sediment control measures.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: NZ should learn from countries with higher populations, like Australia and Europe, as to how best to protect water quality in urban areas.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Improvements in water quality are best achieved by improvements in land management practices, such as stormwater controls in urban areas.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The National Freshwater Policy Statement does not directly result in improvements to water quality.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: NZ needs better integration of land and water management.  Modern sources of water pollution largely stem from poor land management.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Minimum flow requirements to protect freshwater ecosystems and recreational use should be set for all rivers and streams.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Everyone has a right to access our freshwater water resource, not just those who own land beside a river/stream or over an aquifer.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: No one should be granted private property rights over vital natural resources such as fresh water.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Our waterways are too important to the ecological balance of our environment to allow private interests to exploit them for economic gain.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The amount of sprays councils use to control weeds around our waterways needs to stop. So is the heavy use of 1080 and Brodifacum.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I think the Government should stop funding big irrigation schemes.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 19. Rivers and aquifers have the ability to come back into balance so a precautionary approach is too time consuming and risk averse.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 24. Industrial water users like horticulture and farming need certainty of supply otherwise they cannot invest.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 23. Industrial users of water are motivated to regulate themselves to a good standard and poor performers will be visible to consumers who can choose other companies.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 13. Industrial water users like horticulture and farming need certainty of supply otherwise they cannot invest.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 11. Waterways should have the inherent right to protection and conservation in an untouched state independently of peopleâ€™s interests in them.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I have personally experienced issues of water quality (eg a boil water notice, a polluted local waterway or water-related gastro infection in the family)
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I am employed by or own a business that relies on freshwater resources
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I work in the field of water management or policy
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I am a farmer or commercial grower
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I am 55 years of age or older
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I am 30 years of age or older but less than 55
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I am under 30 years of age
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I access tapwater from a town, rural or urban water supply
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I do now or have in the past regularly used freshwater bodies for recreational activities
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I live within 20km of a freshwater body (Creek, Stream, lake, river)
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I live in a rural area
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I live in a town
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I live in a city
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 22. We need to adopt innovative and clean new water technologies and agriculture techniques now to ensure we have abundant and clean water supplies for the future
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 21. We need a national water fund contributed to by water polluters and extractors which would be used to improve water quality.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 20. Water should be held and governed collectively in trust for all citizens and we should all have equal say in its use and equal dividends in profits from its exploitation.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 19. Where there is not enough data or scientific evidence around the effects of water activities, a precautionary approach must be taken to ensure no negative future consequences.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 18. Those making profits from water extraction or using water as waste disposal should be paying for the privilege.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 17. There should be greater accountability and enforcement of rules against pollution.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 16. All interested parties including appropriate Maori groups should be involved in decisions about the sustainable and long term use of each water catchment.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 15. Some freshwater catchment areas are simply too ecologically important or unsuitable for certain water activities to take place.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 14. We need a clear and inclusive National framework and institutions for making decisions about major water projects.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 13. It is not Governmentâ€™s place to clean up waterways - it should be left to the industries involved to self regulate.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 12. Protecting all endangered native freshwater flora and fauna is an urgent priority.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 11. Waterways are a gift of nature and should have the inherent right to protection and conservation in an untouched state independently of peopleâ€™s interests in them.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 10. Treaty of Waitangi claims over ownership of freshwater resources must be resolved as was done with fisheries before a truly sustainable and effective allocation regime is possible.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 9. More funds should be available to Iwi and other groups to enable Maori to play a more engaged role in protecting or restoring waterways.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 8. Treaty of Waitangi commitments mean Maori access to clean waterways and freshwater food sources must be protected now and for future generations.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 7. Subsidising irrigation projects with millions of dollars of taxpayer money is justified as it will benefit the overall economy.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 6. Farmers should have the right to use the water flowing through their land to irrigate or to dispose of waste products.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 5. Businesses that pollute water over a nationally accepted level should pay a penalty.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 4. Businesses that meet acceptable national water quality standards should be rewarded to incentivise such behaviour.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 3. All NZers have the right to access safe and clean freshwater from the tap for drinking, cooking, sanitation and watering plants.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 2. All NZ waterways should be safe to swim, fish, boat or perform other recreational activities in.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: All NZers have the right to access safe and clean freshwater from the tap for drinking, cooking, sanitation and watering plants.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: All NZ waterways should be clean enough to swim, fish, boat and perform other recreational activities in.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 1. There is a freshwater management crisis in New Zealand and something must be done about it.
comments.author: Anonymous
